title: DS310.07 Inverted Indexes | DataStax Enterprise 6 Search
description:
#DataStaxAcademy #DS310
DS310.07 Inverted Indexes
At the center of DSE Search is the inverted index, which we'll learn more about in this section. 

LEARN FOR FREE at https://academy.datastax.com -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.

ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.

transcript.text: [Music] hello my name is daniel farrell a staff member here at datastax and it is my extreme pleasure to carry you a bit farther into your investigation of dse search previously we detailed elements of the dse search runtime environment and a number of the queries you can run using both dsc core and now dse search in this section we move into the topics of actually creating and then managing dsc search indexes at the center of dse search text analytics is the inverted index we preface this discussion as dse search because dse core uses a different index type which is best suited for what dse core means to deliver that being time constant lookups and an always-on operational capability and we preface this discussion as text analytics because dsc search also delivers scalar search and geospatial spatial search capabilities we saw in a previous section where we queried integers date times location data and more using dse search there are also dse search queries as we soon detail but are not text analytics requiring the additional constructs we use specifically when searching text here we see a diagram of two labels rows and inverted index rows is meant to represent a common database index a primary key value of some sort may be used to locate the whole of the record stored in a table primary key value is used to locate the remainder of the descriptive values the attributes the non-key columns of any particular row find the whole of an order row by order number the order date the order payment status the order ship date or other find the whole of a customer role by customer id the customer first name last name the customer primary billing address postal code or other the point is the non-key portions of the row the values are retrieved by a unique identifying key value contrast this with the expected use case for an inverted index with an inverted index the values the descriptive elements in a row are stored as the index key values take the text the plot summaries for all movies to find movies about a lawyer a civil rights case as told from the perspective of a young child and the movie should be based on an award-winning book inverted indexes and dse search support such queries to aid in the indexing of text dsc search indexes are programmable in the way that they tokenize text that is how the words in a sentence are recognized and stored how the tokens in a document are identified and indexed in an inverted index the term lawyer is stored as a key value along with all the movies that have lawyer as a descriptive element which movies are values attributes to the key value lawyer in a common database index rows the attribute lawyer would be stored in a distinct column why do we mention tokens at all isn't it obvious to index all the words in a sentence let's find out here we have a number of movie ids and text movie descriptions that we use in the example that follows give special notice to the tokens australia cop dystopic and crime written as the previous example rows were input into dse their descriptive text was configured to be indexed by dse search australia as a token was found to exist in only movie id cop as a token was found to exist in all movie ids the token dystopic was found for movie ids 2 and 3. notice that all the key values were folded to lower case to aid in finding rows australia is a proper noun and should be capitalized but what if the end user did not query as such and what about cop what if cop always appeared as the first word in every sentence and was capitalized before it was indexed notice the term crime ridden was split on punctuation and indexed as two separate terms should crime ridden have been indexed as one term would the end user have spelled crime written correctly in all cases all of the above and much more are programmable configurable when using dse search and here we have a simple dsc search query to find movies addressing the dystopic nests in their movie description this dse search query predicate could have been lengthened to serve much more advanced queries like not australia yes crime ridden and more importantly dystopic and all from the same dsc search index dse search will match or exclude all tokens as instructed by the query predicates and produce a set of unique movie ids it is at this point expectedly that dsc core will produce the full movie listing for each of the release date director other to the calling function presumably an end user application of some sort
